Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the amount of money that was cut from school safety by stating it as $300 million, when the actual cut was closer to $200 million.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence to support the assertion that the cut in school safety funding could have prevented the Parkland shooting.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the presence of an armed police officer would have been sufficient to stop the Parkland shooter, without considering other factors and circumstances.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim fails to acknowledge that previous presidents, including George W. Bush, also attempted to end the Safe and Drug-Free Schools program, suggesting that the decision to cut funding was not solely made by the Obama administration.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that while the formula-driven program was eliminated, Obama requested additional funding for a companion program that distributed grants on a case-by-case basis.
Understate: The claim may understate the range of activities and initiatives that were funded by the Safe and Drug-Free Schools program, suggesting that it solely focused on armed guards or security measures.
Falters at times: The claim falters by presenting a simplified and potentially misleading representation of the complex budgetary decisions and programs related to school safety.
